summary_points: 1. Todd Horvath, Executive Vice President and President of U.S. Information Solutions, departed Equifax Inc. on June 1, 2025, resulting in a $2.9 million severance payment and a forfeited equity award.
2.  Horvath received a further $3.2 million in cash to compensate him for foregoing unvested equity at his prior employer.
3.  Equifax Inc. will calculate and pay out a prorated portion of Horvath's 2025 annual incentive award in the first quarter of 2026, based on the company's full-year 2025 performance.

1. On May 30, 2025, ServiceNow, Inc. filed a prospectus supplement with the SEC allowing for the resale of 468,499 shares of common stock by certain stockholders; these shares were acquired during the acquisition of Logik.io Inc.
2.  A legal opinion from Freshfields US LLP, concerning the validity of the shares, was also filed.
3. No future impacts or risks were explicitly stated in this section of the filing.

1. On May 29, 2025, LyondellBasell Industries N.V. amended its $900 million structured accounts receivable facility, extending its term to June 26, 2026, and updating certain terms to align with its senior unsecured revolving credit facility.
2. As of May 29, 2025, there were no trade receivable purchases or letters of credit outstanding under the Receivables Facility.
3.  The amendment to the Receivables Facility, effective May 29, 2025, has no other materially changed terms.

1. Meta Platforms, Inc. held its annual shareholder meeting on May 28, 2025, where shareholders voted on fourteen proposals, including the election of fifteen directors and the approval of the 2025 Equity Incentive Plan.
2.  Shareholders approved the 2025 Equity Incentive Plan with 3,753,643,849 votes in favor,  1,235,628,986 against, and 4,330,186 abstentions.
3.  Shareholders voted on a non-binding advisory basis to hold future advisory votes on executive compensation every three years, a policy that will remain in effect until the 2031 annual meeting.
1. Eversource Energy signed an Equity Distribution Agreement on May 30, 2025, with 12 investment banks allowing them to sell up to $1,200,000,000 of common shares.
2. This new agreement, effective May 30, 2025, replaces a prior agreement dated May 11, 2022.
3.  The sale of shares will be made only by means of a prospectus and related prospectus supplement, filed on May 30, 2025.
1. As of April 30, 2025, the company had $2,585.4 million in total outstanding debt, a slight increase from $2,583.7 million on October 31, 2024.
2.  The company anticipates $22.0 million in losses from a component of "Accumulated other comprehensive loss" to be realized in the next twelve months, contingent on prevailing interest rates.

3. On May 1, 2024, the company entered into a new Revolving Credit Agreement with a $2,300.0 million credit facility maturing on May 1, 2029, and an option to increase this or establish a new term loan up to $1,150.0 million or 100% of EBITDA.

1. At the May 28, 2025 Annual Meeting, Chevron Corporation stockholders approved amendments to eliminate the monetary liability of certain officers,  a change to the Restated Certificate of Incorporation effective May 28, 2025.

2.  The proposal to amend the Company’s Charter to provide for officer exculpation received 62.51% of the outstanding shares in favor, while a stockholder proposal to commission a third-party report on human rights practices received only 10.5% approval.

3. Several stockholder proposals were not approved, including those related to renewable energy stranded asset risks (1.5% approval) and allowing holders of 10 percent of common stock to call special meetings (24.7% approval).
1. Humana Inc. amended and restated its existing credit agreement on May 30, 2025, increasing its borrowing capacity from $2.642 billion to $5.0 billion.
2.  This increase represents a $2.358 billion (89.2%) rise in available credit compared to the previous agreement.
3. The agreement allows for an additional $1.0 billion in incremental commitments, increasing potential future borrowing capacity.
1. Target Corporation reported $23.8 billion in net sales for the three months ended May 3, 2025, compared to $24.5 billion for the same period in 2024.
2. In March 2025, Target settled credit card interchange fee litigation, recording a $593 million pretax gain (net of legal fees) within Selling, General, and Administrative Expenses.
3.  As of May 3, 2025, Target had $3.3 billion in outstanding vendor obligations eligible for early payment under supplier finance programs.
1. At Exxon Mobil Corporation's May 28, 2025 Annual Meeting, 83.9% of outstanding shares were voted, with shareholders electing all twelve director nominees and ratifying the independent auditors.
2.  Darren W. Woods received the lowest percentage of "For" votes for the election of directors at 94.2%, while Michael J. Angelakis received the highest at 97.5%.
3. The advisory vote to approve executive compensation resulted in 92% of votes cast being "For" and 8% being "Against," with abstentions and broker non-votes also recorded.

1. As of May 9, 2025, TJX amended its credit facilities, extending the maturity of its 2028 facility to May 9, 2029, increasing its principal amount to $750 million, and extending the maturity of its 2026 facility to May 9, 2030, while decreasing its principal amount to $750 million and adjusting the interest rate margin.
2.  TJX's total long-term debt decreased by $1 million from February 1, 2025 to May 3, 2025.
3.  Within the next 12 months, tax audit resolutions could potentially reduce unrecognized tax benefits by up to $21 million, lowering the provision for taxes on earnings.

1. On May 20, 2025, McKesson Corporation issued $2,000,000,000 in notes, with varying interest rates and maturity dates (ranging from 2030-2035), to fund the acquisition of a 70% stake in Community Oncology Revitalization Enterprise Ventures, LLC.
2.  The net proceeds from the note offering were approximately $1,989.7 million.

3.  The notes include provisions for optional redemption, allowing McKesson to redeem the notes prior to maturity at a make-whole premium plus accrued interest,  and mandatory repurchase in the event of a change of control coupled with a credit rating downgrade.
1. At GE HealthCare Technologies Inc.'s annual meeting on May 28, 2025, a stockholder proposal regarding ratification of certain termination pay arrangements was not approved.
2.  The election of 10 directors for a one-year term, until the 2026 annual meeting, received between 341,857,959 and 357,114,041 votes for, with votes against ranging from 868,691 to 13,735,653.
3. Deloitte & Touche LLP was ratified as the independent auditor for the fiscal year ending December 31, 2025, receiving 396,526,420 votes for.

1. EOG Resources' $5.6 billion acquisition of Encino Acquisition Partners, LLC, announced on May 30, 2025, is projected to immediately increase 2025 EBITDA by 10%, cash flow from operations by 9%, and free cash flow by 9%.
2. The acquisition is expected to close in the second half of 2025, adding over 12 billion barrels of oil equivalent to EOG's total net resources.
3.  Synergies from the Encino Acquisition are projected to exceed $150 million in the first year post-acquisition.

1. On May 30, 2025, American Tower Corporation completed a registered public offering of €500 million of 3.625% senior unsecured notes due 2032, receiving net proceeds of approximately €496.8 million ($558.4 million).
2. The net proceeds will be used to repay existing indebtedness under a $6.0 billion credit facility and for general corporate purposes.

3.  The indenture governing the notes includes covenants limiting the company's ability to merge, consolidate, or sell assets, and to incur liens, subject to certain exceptions, including a 3.5x Adjusted EBITDA threshold for lien-secured indebtedness.
1. Invitation Homes' new lease rate growth significantly improved to 2.5% for April and May 2025, compared to -0.1% in Q1 2025.
2.  As of May 30, 2025, Invitation Homes had over 1,800 homes under construction in its build-to-rent pipeline.
3.  Invitation Homes projects approximately 6% investment yields on its build-to-rent developments.

1. Synopsys has suspended its financial guidance for Q3 fiscal year 2025 and the full fiscal year 2025 due to new export restrictions related to China announced by the Bureau of Industry and Security.
2.  The SEC filing was made on May 29, 2025, following the announcement of Synopsys’ financial results for the second fiscal quarter ended April 30, 2025.
3. Synopsys is currently assessing the potential impact of these new export restrictions on its business, operating results, and financial condition.
